thread.title: St. Mary's grad, a rare female jet fighter pilot, part of Navy football flyover
thread.title_full: St. Mary's grad, a rare female jet fighter pilot, part of Navy football flyover

author: Wendi Winters
title: St. Mary's grad, a rare female jet fighter pilot, part of Navy football flyover
text:
In elementary school, she told her mother, Kathleen, the drama instructor and play director at St. Mary's High School, she wanted to be the first woman to land on the moon. 
"She's always wanted to fly," said her mom. 
She said her daughter, a systems engineering major, graduated among the top in the Naval Academy Class of 2010 with a GPA of 3.9, and had been Co-Commander of 7th Company. 
The oldest of four, Ruttum was a St. Mary's "lifer," attending the downtown Catholic school from kindergarten through 12th grade. Ranked 3rd in her class, she was awarded the 2010 Patriot League Scholar Athlete of the Year Award. 
Though no one in her family had served in the Navy, the Ruttum clan enjoys watching the Midshipmen parade through downtown to football games and participates in events on the Yard. 
During her sophomore year, Ruttum first considered the Naval Academy for college. Attending a weeklong Summer Seminar at the end of her junior year, she discovered she could handle the Academy's rigors, challenges and its regimen. 
Ruttum is one of about four female single seat F/A-18 pilots in the U.S. Navy. 
"The women ahead of me had to deal with a lot more negativity than I have," she said. 
She credits time management she learned at St. Mary's and honed at the Naval Academy for her success on land and in the air. And to younger women who might be inspired by her example, she has some advice: 
"Our being a woman in this time and day, we have opportunities women in the past fought for us to have — and women in other countries still don't have," she said. "You shouldn't let the perception of prejudice that exists in male-dominated jobs keep you from trying — or flying."
